Train Models (Create Jobs)Â¶

A Job is a Resource that specifies all aspects of a computation job. It aggregates 3 things:

  1. What to run

  2. How to run it

  3. Where to run it

A user can execute a job via the CLI by executing an az ml job create command. The examples below encapsulate how a user might expand their job definition as they progress with their work.

Create your first jobÂ¶

For this example, weâll simply clone the v2 preview repo and run the first example!

git clone https://github.com/Azure/azureml-v2-preview

Check that a compute cluster exists in your workspace and you have a compute cluster named goazurego (if not, you can modify the name of the cluster in your YML file).

az ml job create --file azureml-v2-preview/examples/train/basic-command-job/hello_python_job.yml

This will run a simple âhello worldâ python script. Here is the YML that we ran.

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/commandJob.schema.json
command: python hello.py
code:
  local_path: src
environment: 
  docker: 
    image: docker.io/python
compute:
  target: azureml:goazurego

Letâs go into more details on the job specification.

Understanding a job specificationÂ¶

The following is a fully fleshed out job specification YML:

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/commandJob.schema.json
code: 
  local_path: train
command: >-
  python train.py 
  --data {inputs.training_data} 
environment: azureml:xgboost-environment:1
compute:
  target: azureml:goazurego
inputs:
  training_data:
    data: azureml:irisdata:1
    mode: mount

code / directory is the path to your code directory relative to where the YML file lives.

  • This directory is uploaded as a snapshot to Azure ML and mounted to your job for execution.

  • All of the files from âdirectoryâ are uploaded as a snapshot before the job is created and can be viewed in the Snapshot page of the run from Studio UI.

command defines the command that gets run on the remote compute.

  • command executes from the root of the code directory defined above.

  • This is typically the command, example: python train.py or Rscript train.R and can include as many arguments as you desire.

environment defines the docker image virtual environment you want to run your job in.

  • azureml: is a special moniker used to refer to an existing entity within the workspace.

  • azureml:AzureML-Minimal:1 is expecting that version 1 of an environment called AzureML-Minimal exists in the current workspace.

  • You can also specify an environment image inline using the syntax in the hello world example above.

compute defines where you want to run your job and compute-specific information

  • target indicates the compute you want to run your job against. For example, azureml:testCompute refers to a compute cluster called âtestComputeâ in the current workspace.

  • You can override the compute (or any parameter) by using ** --set compute.target=azureml:cpu-cluster **

inputs defines data you want mounted or downloaded for your job.

  • data is the reference pointer to the dataset you want to use

  • mode indicates how you want the data made available in the job. Mount and Download are the two supported options.

name is the (optional) user defined run identifier which needs to be unique. If you do not provide a name a GUID name will be generated for you. - By default, runs are tagged with the experiment name âDefaultâ. If you want to use a different experiment name, you can use the parameter experiment_name. - --name and other parameters can be overwritten from the command line. For example: az ml job create --file azureml-v2-preview/examples/commandjob.yml --name test2

Real training examplesÂ¶

Hereâs an example that runs Python code.

az ml environment create --file examples/train/tensorflow/tf_env.yml
az ml job create --file examples/train/tensorflow/mnist/tf_mnist_job.yml

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/commandJob.schema.json
experiment_name: tf-mnist
code: 
  local_path: ./src
command: python train.py
environment: azureml:tf-environment:1
compute:
  target: azureml:goazurego

Hereâs an example that runs R code:

az ml job create --file examples/train/r/accident-prediction/r_job.yml

experiment_name: r-accidents-example
code:
  local_path: ./src
command: >-
  Rscript accidents.R
  --data {inputs.training_data}
environment:
  docker:
    build:
      dockerfile: file:../r.dockerfile
compute:
  target: azureml:goazurego
inputs:
  training_data:
    data: azureml:accidentsdata:1
    mode: mount

Train an XGBoost modelÂ¶

Next, letâs train an xgboost model on an IRIS dataset.

Letâs navigate to the examples/iris directory in the repository and see what we should do next.

cd ./examples/iris/

Define your environmentÂ¶

First we are going to define the xgboost environment we want to run.

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/environment.schema.json
name: xgboost-environment
version: 1
conda_file: file:xgboost_conda.yml
docker: 
  image: mcr.microsoft.com/azureml/intelmpi2018.3-ubuntu16.04:20210301.v1

az ml environment create --file xgboost_env.yml

Upload data to the cloudÂ¶

Next the input data needs to be moved to the cloud â therefore the user can create a data artifact in the workspace like so:

az ml data upload -n irisdata -v 1 --path ./data

The above command uploads the data from the local folder .data/ to the workspaceblobstore (default). It creates a data entity and registers it under the name irisdata.

Create your xgboost training jobÂ¶

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/commandJob.schema.json
code: 
  local_path: train
command: >-
  python train.py 
  --data {inputs.training_data} 
environment: azureml:xgboost-environment:1
compute:
  target: azureml:goazurego
inputs:
  training_data:
    data: azureml:irisdata:1
    mode: mount

To submit the job:

az ml job create --file iris_job.yml --name <unique name> --query metadata.interaction_endpoints.studio

The query parameter will return just the studio url for the run, rather than the entire job object. To view the entire job object, we can use the CLI to show this job:

az ml job show <name of previous job>

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/commandJob.schema.json
command: >-
  python train.py
  --data {inputs.training_data}
environment: azureml:xgboost-env:1
compute:
  target: azureml:<compute-name>
code:
  directory: train
inputs:
  training_data:
    data: azureml:irisdata:1
    mode: mount

The above job can be run without reference to the dataset, by removing the inputs and the arg in the command, since the script sets the default value if no data is input. This is to allow further debugging if data store does not work.

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/commandJob.schema.json
command: >-
  python train.py
environment: azureml:xgboost-env:1
compute:
  target: azureml:<compute-name>
code:
  directory: train

Sweep Jobs (Hyperparameter Tuning)Â¶

A Sweep job executes a hyperparameter sweep of a specific search space for a job. The below example uses the command job from the previous section as the âtrialâ job in the sweep. It sweeps over different learning rates and subsample rates for each child run. The search space parameters will be passed as arguments to the command in the trial job.

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://azuremlsdk2.blob.core.windows.net/latest/sweepJob.schema.json
experiment_name: tune-iris-example
algorithm: random
type: sweep_job
search_space:
  learning-rate:
    type: uniform
    min_value: 0.001
    max_value: 0.1
  subsample:
    type: uniform
    min_value: 0.1
    max_value: 1.0    
objective:
  primary_metric: accuracy
  goal: maximize
trial:
  command: >-
    python train.py --data {inputs.training_data}
  environment: azureml:xgboost-environment:1
  compute:
    target: azureml:goazurego
  code: 
    local_path: train
  inputs:
    training_data:
      data: azureml:irisdata:1
      mode: mount
limits:
  max_total_trials: 10
  max_concurrent_trials: 10
  timeout_minutes: 20

This can be executed by running (after setting compute name in yaml):

az ml job create --file iris_sweep.yml
